<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.2 is: Functions shall not call themselves, either directly or indirectly.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_uio_dev_close:
```c
static void metal_uio_dev_close(struct linux_bus *lbus,
				struct linux_device *ldev)
{
	(void)lbus;
	unsigned int i;

	for (i = 0; i < ldev->device.num_regions; i++) {
		metal_unmap(ldev->device.regions[i].virt,
			    ldev->device.regions[i].size);
	}
	if (ldev->override) {
		sysfs_write_attribute(ldev->override, "", 1);
		ldev->override = NULL;
	}
	if (ldev->sdev) {
		sysfs_close_device(ldev->sdev);
		ldev->sdev = NULL;
	}
	if (ldev->fd >= 0) {
		close(ldev->fd);
	}
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function metal_uio_dev_close:
int metal_unmap(void *mem, size_t size)
{
	return munmap(mem, size) < 0 ? -errno : 0;
}
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
if (ldev->fd >= 0) {
		close(ldev->fd);
	}
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 17.2 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: The fragment calls the POSIX close(fd) function. close is not metal_uio_dev_close and does not call metal_uio_dev_close, so there is no direct or indirect self-call in this code path. Therefore Rule 17.2 is not violated.
